Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story:
I was standing in the crowded polling station, clutching my phone, my heart pounding. My sister’s text had just come through: “I need you. Please call me.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. I could picture her, alone in her apartment, probably crying. I wanted to run to her, to be the sister she could always count on, just like we promised after Mom died.

But the election official was in front of me, clipboard in hand, explaining that my registration didn’t match. “You’ll need to fill out this provisional ballot form,” she said, “and you have ten minutes before we close.” Her tone was firm, and the line behind me was restless. I knew the rules—follow every instruction, don’t hold up the process, do my civic duty.

I stared at the form, my phone buzzing again. My sister needed me now, but so did my responsibility as a voter. The pressure from both sides squeezed my chest. I felt torn in two, desperate not to let either role down, but knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
